job_title: Inpatient Care Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Amazing people to work with even outside your discipline
Collective goal to strive for the best for patients and care a lot about patients
Social Work/Care Management team greatly supportive to one another
If starting out early in your social work career, you can learn a lot and gain good experience
Nice office/great location to work/clean & new hospital
Over the past couple years, upper leadership started to listen to CM concerns about workload/dept structure
cons:
Below average standard of pay compared to national average and other Chicago hospitals
Annual raises are based on "performance" but usually are never above 1.5% and no bonuses 
Caseload is above national average and very demanding
High stress and burnout
Takes immense effort as a department to get upper leadership to hear concerns and enact change
Department is not valued like other departments although they are essential part of the inpatient team. 
CMs don't receive the same level of perks as nurses, therapists, and MDs.
No growth opportunities. You will likely stay in the same role doing the same thing for however many years you stay there.

pros:
RIC is just an amazing place.   We serve people who have been tragically injured in accidents or who are dealing with serious diseases and coming to grips with life-altering impairments that they never imagined would be their fate.  I’m proud to work at the hospital that is number one in the country at helping these patients get better – in many cases beyond what they had imagined would be possible.  Our docs, nurses and therapists are incredible and have been recognized in every way possible for the quality of the work they do.   We also have researchers right in the hospital who invent devices and therapies that can help our patients quickly – so as a hospital we are always getting better, improving our practices and delivering better outcomes.   

We are a year away from moving into a new research hospital that will allow us to deliver a new model of integrating researchers, scientists, doctors and therapists.  They will all work side by side, surrounding the patient and be totally focused on outcomes
cons: Our current building is small and lackluster.  We’re bursting at the seams.  Somehow everyone works around its limitations but I can’t wait to move into the new hospital!

pros: they give good benefits. health care
cons: therapists are overworked and none of the research is relevant to patient care

review_title: Great People to work with, Organization Lacking in Growth Opportunities
pros: RIC has many great people to work with and it gets you exposed to patient care with so many different types of patients with different disabilities.  Staff camaraderie is great and many smart people work there and are willing to bounce ideas off each other to excel programs for patient care.
cons: RIC as an organization is a great self-promoter that they are the best in Rehab patient care in the U.S., which is deceiving.  The pay staff nurses, PCTs, PTs, OTs, PTAs very little compared to their market value, usually in the 25th to 35th percentile in Chicago.  Annual raises are often less than inflation (around 1.25%) and it's impossible to get the top raise unless you get employee of the year.  Annual bonus consists of a fleece blanket (no joke)!  Tuition reimbursement is no longer and the premium withholding for Health/Dental keeps on getting more and more each year.

pros: Great place for researchers to work on advanced technology and for interns/academics to build their resumes.
cons:
Mary clinicians are overloaded, at risk for burn out. Administrative areas are worse -- dysfunctional, under-staffed with high turnover, low morale.  RIC attracts talented people, dazzled by its image, but this is a highly-orchestrated, expertly-crafted product of the branding machine that is RIC’s true focus, and new employees are often disappointed to find the work environment doesn’t live up to the hype.  Culture is bizarrely secretive and fear-based.  CEO is brusk and insensitive, displaying personal warmth only when it serves her agenda.  Urgency is attached to petty issues/tasks while larger problems fester.  Expect long, stressful days catering to the whims of micromanaging executives who aren’t interested in your opinion.   To fill gaps caused by the constant churn, executives make short-sighted, desperate staffing decisions that damage careers.  

#1 Hospital rating is not based on quality of care or patient satisfaction, but on doctor opinions likely influenced by prior year #1 ratings.  Patient satisfaction is only recently a priority because ratings will become public and will determine how much Medicare pays.  Focus on image-crafting is based on a desperate need to raise money to build a new, expensive hospital. Wealthy patients are given special attention due to potential for donating money.  Staffing is lean and salaries leaner, except for top execs (see for yourself on guidestar.org).

pros:
The patients and families, hands down! I’m admin here so I don’t do patient care, but just talking with patients and families, you understand how important RIC is to them. It’s inspiring. I always feel like I make a difference and have never felt such strong purpose. No matter what I work on, I’m helping RIC help patients. Being surrounded by the best doctors and therapists and scientists, and such brave patients, it feels like a huge privilege to work here, even after more than 2 years full-time. 

The mentoring and learning opportunities are great. I’m mentored in my job duties, but I’m also mentored by the people who care for patients so that I learn about our patients and what we do to treat them that has made RIC the best. It’s great for your resume, but it’s even greater for your life.

“Visionary” is an overused term, but sometimes it applies. The CEO truly is a visionary. Messages from the top down are 1) make life better for our patients, 2) excellence is the baseline, 3) creativity and change are essential to help our patients get better and better and better.
cons: RIC has grown way beyond our main building. Quarters are tight, but everyone is really excited about the new hospital.

pros: #1 for 30 years in rehabilitation
cons: Covid-19 patients are admitted here.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits and great coworkers
cons: Hard work and pay isnt great for amount of work

review_title: Nice Place to Work, but room for Improvement
pros: Great people and environment, pays well for the role and good benefits
cons: Moving up is hard, Management isn't flexible

pros: Patients Are completely inspiring every day
cons: Manipulative management , dishonest, untrustworthy, retaliatory

review_title: State of the Art New Hospital
pros: Patients' length of stay is anywhere from 2-12 or more weeks.  You really get to know your patients and families.  You truly make a difference, and you are very much appreciated by the families you serve.  Teamwork is on point also - nurses, PCTs, doctors, and therapists work together to achieve high levels of patient satisfaction and greater patient outcomes.  I've worked at many hospitals, and the teamwork here is unparalleled.  Nurses were all just given a 10% raise, so pay is extremely competitive.
cons: You are ALWAYS short-staffed.  Always.  I understand that this is a problem at all hospitals, but having 8 patients to 1 nurse during a PM shift is absolutely unsafe.

pros: Education benefits, ability to promote from within, great location.  You can learn a great deal but be prepared for burn out.  Patients are inspiring and the new hospital is promising.
cons: Very under staffed, administrative staff are doing 2 jobs for every one person with no end in sight. Very unfriendly to those with families given the sick time policy. Staffing on the clinical side is very unorganized and nonefficient.  No consistency in HR policies, every Manger and Director run their own program.  A great deal of "protected" staff.  It is shocking they are not sued more for HR concerns. Staff salaries in some areas are well under market value and in others they are over.

pros: I've been very impressed with the caliber of individuals who work at RIC and their passion for both the patients and research. They are making strategic investments to ensure the organization keeps growing, including a state of the art hospital and they are not afraid to reinvent themselves along the way. My manager has been incredibly supportive and allowed me to build something new within the organization. My role is very entrepreneurial and I have loved how receptive everyone has been to my recommendations. The past year has been a lot of fun!
cons: Many employees have been here for years, which is great for institutional knowledge, but also can be a challenge when you are growing and changing. I often have to challenge the status quo and get push back when I ask why something is done the way it is done from staff.

review_title: PR posts fake reviews on here
pros: Good location, new facility is nice
cons: As you read through these reviews, please know that public relations at SRAL (formerly RIC) writes fake reviews for Glassdoor and if they don't post them themselves, they ask employees to post them. I know this for a fact, as a few of my colleagues were approached to do so and ended up posting what they had written. This was not really framed as optional, but as "this comes from the top and there will be consequences if you don't do it." So basically instead of actually improving work conditions at this place, they decide to dupe all the poor souls who think this could be a good place to work, since SRAL is luckily still riding on the coattails of the success it had under the leadership of Dr. Betts.

job_title: Patient Financial Services Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: The work we do with patients is outstanding and innovative. The hospital staff has great attitudes and seem happy to be apart of RIC.
cons: Horrible management team! Staff is not allowed to talk to one another, nasty emails from managers, managers not communicating with staff unless its something negative, low moral due to management team, low pay, high work volume, under staffed and over worked. One manager will berate and embarrass her team members on the floor with condescending remarks in front of the staff. The Exec Dir is self centered, and condescending and this is how her management team treats their staff members. There is no bonus or reward system for meeting very high goal expectations. All other departments in the office have high moral and work together well but not at PFS.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Amazing staff from the nurses to housekeeping. Great rapport with each other that lead to amazing teamwork. Surrounded by people who love what they do and genuinely work hard to help the patients and family members. Nurse manager approved schedule changes with no problem. You get a raise after your evaluation every year. Great vacation/sick pay.
cons: At the time I had worked there, the break room was small and there was not a huge selection in the cafeteria for employees to choose from. Also there wasn't a good discount for employees in the hospital cafeteria. Sometimes too understaffed. The higher ups don't seem to care much about the nurses or techs because they spend the hospital budget on unnecessary things rather than giving staff higher pay or bonuses unlike other hospitals around them.

review_title: Part of something bigger than myself
pros: I'm so proud to work for this institution. It was already the leading rehabilitation hospital in the country, but that wasn't good enough. With our new hospital, we're bringing doctors and researchers together, surrounding the patients, in the name of faster recoveries and cures. It's not been done before, is incredibly bold, and will make a lasting impact on patients' lives.
cons: We've been in the new hospital for a few weeks and it's everything our former hospital was not--bright, plenty of space, inspiring. It's essentially entirely open/hybrid office throughout--in clinical, research and administrative spaces. I like it; the environment feels really collaborative and there are plenty of spaces to get work done. Others might not be as open to this set up.

pros: The co-workers and cross functional teams of "lesser than directors and executive leadership" are top class. They truly care about the mission and their patients. Also highly intelligent and forward thinking due caring about to the actual vision of the institution.
cons: It is an emotionally abusive environment. Constantly told to employees that their jobs could be terminated for not taking their vacation and working through it. There is no place to go to navigate problems with direct mangers without being thrown under a bus by directors and HR, given an ultimatum that you will be fired if you complain about a job you should be "grateful you have". Executive leadership is confusing and taking advantage of their employees.

pros: Excellent learning opportunities including employee mentoring, academic programming, discipline-specific CEUs, research participation, growth rotations. The new building and its resources are beautiful and unparalleled.
cons: Therapists have a limited shelf life here due to low pay plus punishing productivity expectations (administrative time leaves one having to make up additional treatment units to stay productive). Overachieving workplace culture and redundant documentation system leads to 1-2 additional hours tacked on to the work day. Annual raises are meager and our  bonus system was just scrapped indefinitely.

review_title: I'm not sure how they have such a great rating
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chicago, IL
pros: Great camaraderie among staff. Everyone really gets along so well on the floor.
cons: That is, they get a long until they need to help you take care of a patient or do their jobs. Then it's every person for him or herself. Patients fall, urinate on themselves, or don't get the additional nursing attention they need because floors are understaffed and the staff that are there will not help. There is no sense of teamwork. It is really frustrating and demoralizing to see coworkers treat patients like this and to see management not do much to correct it.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator Flex Staff in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Hospital. Very important to the national and international community. The staff are really friendly. Was offered an opportunity after the conclusion of my internship. Cafe and lunch room equipped quite nicely. Perks in varying discounts for lunch and Divvy bikes to name a few. I was very proud to work for an organization with prestige.
cons: Hours varied and changes in my schedule occurred quite often, some even last minute. I was wrongfully terminated after my new manager blatantly mislead HR. HR found the my manager did mislead them and did nothing about it. I dedicated most of my lunch hours to working extra in order get things done. Not a lot of African Americans in managers roles, If any.

review_title: Was a good place, but patient care is suffering
pros: It was a great place when I joined.  The focus was on patient care, and it remains a world renown hospital and a leader in rehabilitiation.  There are people who have been there for their entire career and truly care about the mission and the patients.  They did their best every day to keep the needs of patients in balance.
cons: Pay is not competitive.  They rely on their name to get employees and then work therapists and nurses until they quit.  The focus seems to have shifted away from patient care and is all about research.  That's why I left.  I wanted to see the care for patients remain at the forefront.

pros:
-Inspiring Mission
-Excellent patient care
-Good pay and benefits
-Great people (co-workers) who work hard every day no matter what
cons:
-No career advancement
-People are randomly laid off for no reason and rest of staff is expected to pick up slack
-Senior Management has no vision for what the organization will look like after the move to the Shirley Ryan Ability Lab or at least it is not shared with staff
-Senior Management will constantly tell you how important you are to the organization, but never actually show you by allowing you to advance in a career path move
-IS department is disorganized and very slow to respond to issues

job_title: Senior Occupational Therapist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great co-workers, lots of speciality services to refer to and learn from including assistive technology, Wheelchair room, prosthetics  & orthotics
cons: Large corporation that doesn't always value the time of the employee including mandatory meetings over lunch or after hours, limited face time or approachability to anyone who actually has control over the day to day work environment. Often time middle management and no control and upper management seems to have limited understanding of daily life on the floor needs / desires of patients and clinicians.

pros: Incredibly innovative with all the bells and whistles for the patients.
cons:
Everything centers around therapy and not patient care. Labs, CT, patient care—IVs, Foley care—all has to wait until there is a break in therapy. There is a HUGE lack of communication if labs are delayed or not done. There is literally no orientation for mid level staff. The current mid level staff are super clique-y and if you don’t fit in, good luck. There is no support from the physician staff either. The residents are grossly overworked and over stressed. 
Upper management is out of touch with the reality of what is actually going on.

pros: Although I've only been with the organization for a short period of time, I am impressed with the mission and the services we provide.  People are truly committed to patient care and outcomes.  There is great compassion and empathy for our patients, who trust us at the most vulnerable time in their lives.  This is indeed a great place to work!!!!!
cons: We have to become more competitive with pay so we can continue to retain and attract top talent.  I would like to see some type of incentive compensation put in place, when financial and personal goals are met.

review_title: Positive Experience, but happy to move on
pros: Some fun "fringe" benefits: being downtown, sporadic (2x/year) masseuses wandering the floor, offering in-chair massages.  It felt good to be a part of helping people, even if my involvement was more tangentially related to patients.
cons: I worked in a research lab, not with patients.  Most of my lab equipment was fairly old, which made some of the work pretty frustrating.  Some of the requirements were also a bit frustrating (time cards/reports).  I feel like I stagnated a little bit; it's hard to advance in that environment.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros:
RIC Is clean. They pay the housekeepers just enough to clean the areas for families to come visit. It's also a healthy community where everyone keeps to themselves but has friends. The bosses are relatively friendly and welcome their new workers.

Patients families will sometimes bring gifts or money. You see your favorite patients thank you for helping them through their journey.
cons:
Despite the new building that's come next year, 2017, and an influx of donations, they refuse to pay their healthcare professionals more. Many workers have left to Northwestern as their bonuses are better. In fact, RIC Spent $500 million on a new building and even had the nerve to ask their workers for donations.  They spent not one dime on its employees. The main goal was to prevent from paying more for Northwesterns garage because we sold ours for Chicago to build a new apartment building.  The majority of working single moms with children who they work hard to provide for. While we get cheap gifts like a speaker or hats, Northwestern Hospital gives out $500.

The patients will regularly call you fatophic, transphobic, racist, sexist, or homophobic slurs because most are handicapped and will never enjoy the same movements as you and I will. The doctors believe they are better than the nurses, PCT, and CNA's despite the latter doing more work than the actual doctors. You will defiantly see someone die and become heavily depressed due to the news that their condition will never change. It's a very emotional job as you will have a minimum of 10 patients, which I guarantee only 40% will leave during your time there. Even if you're not involved with nursing but housekeeping, it can become really dirty.

review_title: The Institute is more than the sum of its parts.
pros:
-Many of the people who work at RIC are amazing.
-Learn a great deal about the community of persons with disabilities--> provides a new way of viewing the world around you. 
-Collaboration is encouraged.
cons:
-Some department heads do not encourage career growth but expects team members to beg for growth opportunities. 
-Expected to do the work of 1-2 positions above your own without promotion or compensation.

review_title: The work culture is unique and passionate about rehabilitation.
pros:
It’s a larger non-profit organization that still feels intimate within each innovation center. 
Exposure to the most interesting and complicated clinical cases.
It’s a beautiful new facility in a stunning part of the city.
cons:
Some of the older traditions and ways are harder to evolve.
Pay is lower.

pros:
Great culture! I had a real opportunity to meet and help people, even as a housekeeper.
You get to see amazing recoveries and can feel good about yourself at the end of the day.
cons: Unfortunately my management team was contracted out and often seemed to be on a different page the the hospital. I felt that there were two different job cultures.

pros: The vision and innovation that RIC puts toward helping people with disabilities is amazing. They have some of the best doctors. Their mission is very positive.
cons: The environment is like high school and management has too much leverage. They go by their own rules . They are very disrespectful and degrading towards minorities. There is a lot of inside unethical practices at RIC.

review_title: High stress and no work life balance
pros: My colleagues are supportive, misery loves company I guess. However, I advise my RN friends not to work here .
cons: High expectations combined with. chronically understaffed departments especially for nursing, therapy and care management. We work through lunch and rarely  take a break. Stay late , forced overtime, unplanned  weekend assignments and typically. Very difficult to get time off one needs , in a word a rather exploitative work environment especially ,for those providing direct patient care.

pros: You are able to make SUCH a difference in a patient's life.  RIC really does absolutely tremendous work.  Everyone who works here truly cares about their patients, and the patients are so very grateful.  Such a rewarding job!
cons: The work is very physically and emotionally draining.

review_title: 1 Year at SRALab during Global Pandemic
pros: Intelligent and ambitious co-workers, opportunities for research, patient-focused 1-on-1 care
cons: Company doesn't value the expertise and hard work of their employees (primarily therapists), we are under paid clinicians because the company knows others would be willing to take their place, not considered a place to stay long term

pros: Cutting edge rehabilitation techniques; diverse and challenging patient population; excellent continuing education and collaboration possibilities; plans for growth (new hospital)
cons: Over-emphasis on assessment, cutting into valued treatment time for patients; disconnect between leadership and front line employees; tendency to attract highly strung uber type A employees; strong emphasis on productivity with extremely little time allotted for meetings and inservices

pros: I couldn't ask for a better place to work. This place is brimming with inspiration from patients and fellow co-workers. I'm so glad to be part of such an incredible community and culture.
cons: Honestly, I think the organization has made significant strides in the last few years. The new hospital is amazing and the leadership team has gone to great lengths to increase employee engagement and communications.

review_title: Research in a hospital setting is challenging and rewarding
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Research is a good work environment, full of smart, dedicated visionaries. Research leadership is very supportive of their staff, although sometimes they must fight the main hospital administration to do so.
cons: As is the case everywhere, budgets are tight and grants are limited. These outward pressures can cause some stress and anxiety in research departments.

review_title: Wanting too much for too little
pros: Some great people.  Mission to help disabled people.
cons: Management doesn't listen or value employee opinion(s) or experience.

pros: The mission is unparalleled. The patients made every day of work worth it.
cons: Some departments are very challenging. They are not run by individuals who know/understand/or implement best practices. They rely completely on "whatever management wants" which leads to lackluster results. It was unfortunate to see.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Chicago, IL
pros: Good pace for new nurses to practice some skills before heading into a different specialty, good interdisciplinary relationships/communication, lots of onsite training available, very education based hospital
cons: Not a ton of room for growth, annual salary increases are very minimal, expect a call asking you to work every single day you have off, constantly short staffed, quick turnover rate

pros: There is a real focus on patient care and positive outcomes here. I feel like my work is recognized and that I am making a difference.
cons: It does seem like it is a little difficult to move into other positions or advance.

job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Great technology fast paced learning can be challenging troubleshooting and repair on site is required
cons: micromangement, not much support from out side vendors can be a stressful environment at times due to the nature of working with individuals with injuries

pros: Great location. Knowing that you are working with the best doctors in physical med & rehab.
cons:
RNs are bottom of the totem pole. Doctors take physical/occupational/speech therapists more seriously. 
I felt floor was understaffed at times compared to the physical workload that rehab med requires.

pros: RIC has really earned it's top spot as the #1 rehabilitation hospital. Most everyone is deeply invested in the spirit of rehabilitation, and it shows in their work. RIC cares where few hospitals do, and in spades.
cons: Being in the middle of downtown Chicago, it can be a difficult commute unless you're in the area.

pros: Making a difference in the patients life.
cons:
Long hours
Little pay
Poor management 
Very tough to get raises
Almost impossible to move up the ladder
Must be extremely flexible with your job duties and time
3 sick days a year
Will get written up for simple things.

What is done for the patients is truly wonderful however, working for the company is just awful. Management is terrible, they don't care about you. You have to love the patients more than yourself and your life.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Hospital has great credentials, beautiful building.
cons: The department's don't want to pay you for the extra tasks you do that aren't in your job description.

job_title: Patient Services Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: My peers were motivated, kind, and compassionate individuals. Excellent health insurance options. Everything else falls to "average".
cons: Money first mentality for a patients forward model. Upper management doesn't have much clue how to run a business, and the trickle down from that is vicious.

pros:
Top Rehabilitation Hospital
Great Mix of people
Good working environment
cons:
Lack of proper hierarchy/ structure for research roles
Not much room for growth with current structure
Not quiet competitive salary as compared to industry standards

pros: What we do for patients is beyond description. To work here is a privilege because you are reminded every day of how human genius can help solve human suffering.
cons: Open seating in some areas makes for too much togetherness sometimes.

review_title: An innovative and cutting edge future with humanity
job_title: Senior Vice President, Chief Administrative Off in Chicago, IL
cons:
Fast-paced environment;
Lots of change happening right now--for the positive but you need to embrace changes.

pros: Great place to work for beginning a new career or just switching employers.
cons: Like all workplacess, you must have one or more advocates in management if you want to move up.

pros:
1)good staff
2) good environment 
3) good patients
4) good physicians to work with 
5) learning facility
cons:
1) not the  best management 
2) not the best equipments 
3) not given proper holiday leaves 
4) not the best communication 
5) under staffed

If you don't want to grow, don't come!
Fast-paced which adds to the excitement!

pros: The salary is pretty good with benefits
cons: The women there remind me of high school and the boss "man" is impatient and quick to hover you. He comes off as not caring of employees and the place is understaffed.

pros: There are some concerned and wonderful people who want to do the best they can for the Institute; but they are few and far between.
cons: Corporate culture there is silo oriented.  They do not seek nor want other viewpoints.

pros: Coworkers are incredibly hard working and care about the patients
cons: The management is not great. Continue to keep management that is lacking any leadership skills. Pay is not comparative, and the excuse is always it is a non profit. That doesn’t stop directors from getting bonuses.

pros: Very cool research and great opportunities to learn new skills
cons: The hiring managers do not return calls/emails as they don’t treat this like a business

job_title: Licensed Physical Therapist in Willowbrook, IL
pros: Absolutely the patients! Ability to make a difference.
cons: Salary. Management. Inconsistent expectations. Micromanagement. Personal dynamics. LONG hours lots of paperwork. Workday is usually 10 hours. Staying late or documenting from home is expected. Leadership feels that the name is worth more than a competitive salary.

pros: Access to world class, top of the line BioMedical Tech research.
cons: Geared towards PhD's, highly connected. Limited growth potential in the research department if you are not on a PhD track. This is academia.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Chicago, IL
pros: SRAL has a great interdisciplinary team work environment and you are able to use clinical skills and judgement to best help patients.
cons: Department is under re-construction at this time.

pros:
- good pay and flexible hours (flex staff) 
- clean environment/work space
- good collaboration with nurses 
- training prepares you well
cons:
-sometimes heavy patient loads
- collaboration with therapy schedules/ therapists can be difficult

pros: Rank #1 in the nation.
cons: Hard to make the balance between the work and family.

job_title: Manager, Outpatient Services in Schererville, IN
pros: Great company committed to its patients, education and the development of 'best practices'.
cons: Pay is not competitive and there is a lack of 'work life balance'.

pros: It feels wonderful to work for the #1 rehabilitation hospital in the united states.
cons: There are no negatives for being a part of the staff.

pros: Great place to start your career; people that work there will support your learning path
cons: Low compensation; You really have to be self-motivated and proactive

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Chicago, IL
pros: Work with amazing experts and families
cons: Hard to watch the frustration and uncontrollable circumstances

pros: Awesome environment, so rewarding and inspirational. People are really friendly.
cons: The work life balance sometimes is going to be tough and prepare for long hours.

pros: Great to have SRAlab on your resume, some floors are better than others.
cons: pay, work environment can be uptight at times

pros: Great nurses and staff that work together as a team
cons: Not enough space for patient care

pros: welcomes new grads, competitive pay
cons: unsupportive environment for new grads, lots of transitional organizational changes

pros: Patient care and satisfaction is priority #1.
cons: Restructuring can be destructive to employee morale.

pros: You get paid every two weeks
cons: Culture is favorable towards certain ethnic groups, very disrespectful towards minorities, very unethical practices, over worked-under paid, little room for advancement depending on ethnicity, Cliquish environment.

pros: Great mission,  clinical care, and patients
cons: Lack of transparency, communication, and leadership support

review_title: A great place for scholars to do research
pros:
1. Nice working environment
2. Decent payroll
3. Good benefits
cons: No cons at all in my opinion.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Coworkers are really great to work with.
cons: The cons do not outweigh the pros and are hard to think of.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Good place to work love seeing the patients
cons: Good place to advance great staff who’s willing to go above and beyond

pros: - great culture and values
cons: - waiting on the new building to open in the Spring of 2017

pros: An exceptional place to work.
cons: No cons come to mind. A terrific employer.

pros: Some great coworkers that are willing to help. Awesome views.
cons: Understaffing especially later shifts and weekends.

pros: Everyone excited about rehabilitation here
cons: There could be more thorough training for new graduates

pros: Friendly, nice place to work
cons: Rehabilitation setting place to work

pros: Great place to do rehabilitation research
cons: not much room to grow

pros: Good location to work. Good hospital
cons: Over worked under staffed, no lunch breaks.

review_title: Least Inclusive Work Environment I've Ever Been In
pros: Consistently ranked as a top tier physical rehabilitation facility in the US.
cons: Unless your a male in Physical Therapy, good luck getting anywhere with this place.

pros: 15 days vacation, health insurance
cons: not a good research environment , the institute do not care about employee
